Your choice of editor

A developer’s choice of editor is a personal decision. An editor is like fashion style; it is liable to change. People in the developer community can be very opinionated about your choice of editor, but at the end of the day use what makes sense to you. I use Emacs because it works well for me.

Emacs history

GNU Emacs was first developed by Richard Stallman. Stallman has developed a cult like following in the open source community, because of his development of Emacs and other projects. The Emacs family of editors has been around for a while. Emacs is a program that lets you edit text, but it does much more. Emacs is written in and runs its own version of lisp. Every time you type or execute a command in emacs your really just running lisp code. This has led to the joke that Emacs is great operating system. With Emacs, you can check your calendar, browse the web, and even write emails. The reason for all of this functionality is that you can be easily extend it using Emac’s lisp.

Getting Started

Out of the box, Emacs won’t look very pretty. You can download a copy from GNU. The first thing I like to do is to disable the menu, tool and scroll bars. You can do this by opening a file called .emacs. Press C-x C-f ( C means to press control so you would hit Control x and then Control f) you should see a menu bar at the bottom. Type .emacs into it and hit enter. A new buffer should appear that is empty. Copy and paste the following lines into the file.

(menu-bar-mode -1) 
(toggle-scroll-bar -1) 
(tool-bar-mode -1)

Then press C-x C-s to save it. Now close Emacs and reopen it, you’ll notice that Emacs now looks more streamlined.

To install a theme, you’ll need to install Melpa. Melpa is package manager that lets you install lots of different Emacs packages. A package manager is something that let’s you easily install others peoples programs. Insert the following into your .emacs. To set up Melpa.

(require 'package)
(setq package-enable-at-startup nil)
(add-to-list 'package-archives
     '("melpa" . "https://melpa.org/packages/"))

(package-initialize)

;; Bootstrap `use-package'
(unless (package-installed-p 'use-package)
(package-refresh-contents)
(package-install 'use-package))

(use-package cyberpunk-theme
 :ensure t)

The code above is taken from c’est la z, a great in depth tutorial on Emacs. When you open and close emacs you’ll see the theme.

If you want to load another theme just change cyberpunk-theme to another theme. Here’s a list of themes.

Spacemacs

Spacemacs is an Emacs distribution that comes with a lot of packages preinstalled. To install it you will need Git. It looks nice but I’ve found it to be too slow for my taste.
